channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: 2 Indian Teenagers Thought to Be Murdered Actually Killed Themselves, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The country’s top investigative agency said that the girls, whose bodies were found hanging from a mango tree, had committed suicide and that no rape or abduction was suspected.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dai Xiang’s Modern Take on a Classic Chinese Painting
item.description: The artist borrows the visual and conceptual framework of “Along the River During the Qingming Festival,” a 12-century painting, to produce a patchwork of vignettes of everyday Chinese society.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A scene showing fishermen demanding payment before handing over the bodies of students who died while trying to save drowning children.

item.title: E.U. Parliament, in Nonbinding Measure, Calls for Breaking Up Google
item.description: While the vote poses no immediate threat to the company, it symbolizes the growing resentment in Europe toward the American technology titan.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Says He Doesn’t Disagree With Extension of Nuclear Talks
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s opinion is crucial, as he has the final say over a potential deal.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Greek Navy Tows Disabled Vessel Carrying Migrants to Safety
item.description: An estimated 700 people were on the 250-foot cargo ship that is now anchored off the Aegean island of Crete, according to the official.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stalin, Father of Ukraine?
item.description: His rule saw the formation of a land with a strong national consciousness, a legacy that Putin prefers to ignore.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN KOTKIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Civil Liberties in Peril Down Under
item.description: Press freedoms are under attack in Australia and New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: By RAYMOND BONNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Sea Change in Greece?
item.description: The strict economic policies of the government have begun to bear fruit and better days now seem possible.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS GAGE

item.title: In France, New Review of 35-Hour Workweek
item.description: The Socialist government is rethinking a law that was meant to create jobs but lately has been criticized for adding to the country’s economic woes.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myriam Bello, 22, is one of nearly 4.5 million workers in France unable to find jobs with at least 35 hours a week. She works 30 hours at a New Look clothing store.

item.title: Malaysian Premier Says Sedition Act Will Stand
item.description: Prime Minister Najib Razak has backed away from his promise to abolish a sweeping law that has been used against the government’s opponents.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Najib Razak, the prime minister, center, said that Malaysia's Sedition Act would instead be reinforced with new provisions.

item.title: Scotland Should Get Increased Powers, Including Over Taxation, Commission Says
item.description: Under new recommendations, the Scottish Parliament would set income tax rates and brackets, and the region would get a larger share of welfare spending and revenue from sales taxes.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Indonesia Formally Pledges to Join China-Sponsored Regional Bank
item.description: Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro has signed an agreement to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, intended to rival organizations like the World Bank.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Taipei Mayor’s Race Could Alter Balance of Taiwan’s Political Power
item.description: A victory for Ko Wen-je, a physician who has cultivated an outsider image, would be a sharp defeat for Taiwan’s governing party in a city considered its stronghold.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks British Embassy Vehicle in Kabul
item.description: The blast, which officials said killed at least five people, was the latest in an escalating bombing campaign in the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bean Sprouts Tainted With Banned Additive Are Again Found in China
item.description: Sprouts produced at a site on the southern outskirts of Beijing were treated with high levels of 6-benzyladenine, a plant hormone, to speed up the growth cycle and make them more attractive to buyers, The Beijing News reported.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:credit: Stew Milne for The New York Times
item.media:description: The additive enhanced the appearance and shortened the growing cycle of the bean sprouts, driving up profits.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Zhang Lifan on the New Chinese Nationalism
item.description: The Chinese historian has become outspoken in recent years on the need for China to undertake ambitious economic and political changes.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:description: Zhang Lifan, a historian whose family has been deeply involved in modern Chinese political life.

item.title: Francis Fraser, Who Cashed In on His Cruelty, Dies at 90
item.description: Known as a British underworld enforcer and once suspected in as many as 40 deaths, Mr. Fraser turned his life of crime into a lucrative retirement by chronicling his own deeds in books and films.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:credit: David Westing/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Francis Fraser, known as Mad Frankie, in London in 1997. Mr. Fraser, a career criminal, was suspected in up to 40 killings.

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Leader’s Sister Has Post in Ruling Party
item.description: North Korea’s state-run news media revealed Thursday that Kim Jong-un’s younger sister had become a senior official at the ruling Workers’ Party.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: President’s Rival to Be Charged as Plotter
item.description: The national prosecutor’s office said on Wednesday that it would charge a prominent opposition leader in what it called a plot to kill President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Rescuers in Yemen Sought American, Officials Say
item.description: A journalist held by a Qaeda affiliate was a target in a raid this week by Special Operations commandos and Yemeni troops, according to U.S. and Yemeni officials.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and SAEED AL BATATI
